Since Glazer last occupied a seat in the directors' box, a waterfall has gushed down from the Stretford End roof, staff have had to plug the gaps in the roof of the Sir Bobby Charlton Stand and sewage has overflown in the toilets.

United have the space to rebuild Old Trafford whilst playing in their current home. There would be no reduced capacities, no loss in matchday revenue, pending their progress in competitions, and no need to query the tenancy rate at the Etihad Stadium.
There is adjacent land United could purchase and there are car parks behind the Stretford End that stretch the length of at least two, maybe three, football pitches.

The Sir Bobby Charlton Stand is the only single-tier stand in the stadium due to the issue of the railway line behind it. That could be bypassed with a new build and 'rotating' the stadium has been proposed.

United would have ample room to accommodate a sizeable fan park, a la City Square at the Etihad. The ticket office, which is behind the Sir Alex Ferguson Stand, has been identified as a prime location for a modern fan experience.

"No f*****g chance," was the reply from a senior United employee when asked if United would ever temporarily relocate to Ashton New Road. Maine Road was United's home between 1946-49 and their first ever European tie - a 10-0 thrashing of Anderlecht - was held at City's ground in 1956.

Everywhere in the Etihad area, bar the blinding green Asda sign, is blue. A bridge links the Etihad and the City Football Academy, where a large City banner bearing the club crest is visible to commuters.

It would be jarring for Reds in their red, white and black bar scarves who walk down Warwick Road to head down Alan Turing Way. Mary D's would have United-supporting visitors without a spray can to daub 'MUFC' on its front door. Nobody at United has seriously floated the idea of renting at City.

"Old Trafford is falling down" is a chant City fans incepted during the October derby and it has been aired everywhere from Manchester to Newport. The stadium has been neglected by the absentee landlords, the Glazer family, and where once it was the grandest in Europe it is now not worthy of hosting matches for the European Championship in 2028.

Appearances matter and the lick of paint on the stadium's exterior in August 2022 was overdue. Images indicate it had not been repainted in well over a decade. The colour transformed from maroon to scarlet red.

The turquoise glass exterior of the east stand, synonymous with early 2000s architecture, is dated. Little wonder non-permanent imagery is often affixed to it. The main entrance to the stadium is housed there, beneath the Sir Matt Busby statue that is proudly placed opposite the trinity bronze of Best, Law and Charlton.

It already arouses aura and supporters will feel nostalgic about that sight in years to come. The words 'Manchester United' are identical to the signage that greeted visitors to the ground as far back as the Fifties.

Anyone who goes to Old Trafford knows the awe-inspiring sight of inside the ground. Ascending the steps of your designated block and heading into the light still stirs the soul. One never tires of seeing its manicured pitch and respondent red seats.

United were once the best-in-class with stadium infrastructure, expanding the north stand in 1995 (in time for Euro 96), adding tiers to the Stretford End and Scoreboard End in 2000 before receiving planning permission for the quadrants in 2004. They were inserted in 2006.

Little has noticeably changed in the last 20 years. The Munich Tunnel was opened on the 50th anniversary of the air disaster in 2008 and the upper exterior of the Stretford End received a makeover to coincide with accommodating more disabled facilities in 2020.

The single-tiered Sir Bobby Charlton Stand has had extensive interior work. The former director of communications Charlie Brooks ordered a drastic makeover of the shabby media facilities in 2019, the players' lounge was restored at Erik ten Hag's behest for the start of this season and the directors' lounge has also had an upgrade, as have hospitality suites. The home dressing room is now plusher, a contrast to the drab surroundings for the away teams.

The Manchester Evening News aptly greeted Ole Gunnar Solskjaer's dismissal with a cracked stadium, along with the cracked badge in November 2021. 'Fix this Theatre of Broken Dreams' implored the headline. Nobody has bothered to do so.

Knocking down Old Trafford would be a symbolic gesture, as much of a logistical one. The uncaring Glazers allowed it to fall into disrepair and it is telling there has not been a single expansion during their ownership of nearly 19 years. New Old Trafford, new era.

The stadium has been left behind by City, Liverpool and Tottenham. United fans used to sing "Barcelona, Real Madrid, they shall make a gallant bid" and the latter have done more than that with the renovated Bernabeu. Camp Nou is being rebuilt.

Sir Jim Ratcliffe has met Manchester mayor Andy Burnham as he awaits approval for his impending investment. "Ratcliffe doing a Fergie and buddying up to those he needs to use," quipped one loyal United figure.

Ratcliffe was born in Failsworth, around the corner from Newton Heath, where United were established in 1878 and played at North Road. It would be bold to take United back to their roots and nearer the city centre when Old Trafford is integral to their identity.
It will need more than another brick in the wall.

headline: Jesse Lingard transfer teaches Manchester United an important lesson
body: Jesse Lingard has been without a club since last summer and his latest move reminds Man Utd of a transfer regret
The headlines write themselves: an unexpected Korea change; a player in need of some Seoul searching; or how everything went South for Jesse Lingard.
The truth is that his transfer should serve as a timely reminder to Manchester United of the importance of knowing when to cash in on a player at the right time.

It has been over three years since he was the headline exit from United in the January transfer window, when he embarked on a loan move to West Ham United, which reinvigorated his career and rebuilt his confidence. Lingard netted nine goals and assisted five goals in just 16 appearances for the club, winning both the Premier League Player and Goal of the Month awards in the process.

He returned to United rejuvenated and, most importantly, worth as much as he ever had been during his time at the club. The squad player was now a star, and they were not short of interest in his signature.

Yet, despite serious interest from a number of clubs, he was assured of a major role to play under Ole Gunnar Solskjaer and was persuaded to stay and to fight for his place. It was a hasty change of mind from both parties following his success at West Ham, and one that didn’t pay off.

United resembled a toddler who has no need for a toy until someone else shows an interest in it. Lingard had no role to play and was free to leave, until it turned out he was actually quite good and they wanted to selfishly keep him for themselves.

Lingard ended up only starting two Premier League matches during his final season at the club, was denied a January exit to West Ham or Newcastle, and was upset when Ralf Rangnick denied him a final farewell appearance against Brentford in May 2022.
A year after they could have sold a squad player when their value was at its peak, they ended up losing him for free instead.

Lingard might still wonder what would have happened had he joined West Ham or Newcastle rather than Nottingham Forest, but he will hope to have no regrets about his move to FC Seoul. This is a transfer about enjoying his football again and getting to experience an entirely new lifestyle and career that have stagnated in the last three years.

It should also serve as another timely reminder to United of the ruthless nature of the sport and why it is often wise to cash in on a squad player while they still retain value rather than keep hold of them out of greed.

That is a transfer policy that looks to have changed under Erik ten Hag, at least. United have aimed to become "smarter" in terms of selling academy graduates, with staff suspecting players are going "stale and sour" if they stay at the club too long without getting an opportunity to play.

Dean Henderson, Anthony Elanga, Zidane Iqbal, Matej Kovar, Teden Mengi, Axel Tuanzebe, Ethan Laird, Charlie Savage, Noam Emeran, and Marc Jurado were all academy graduates who were allowed to leave last summer.

Yet, it still isn't perfect. Anthony Martial will leave for free this summer, when he could previously have been sold, and they will have a job on their hands trying to shift Donny van de Beek as well.
Lingard's switch to South Korea is another reminder of what might have been and, at the same time, a warning of what could happen again.
United's transfer strategy is 'smarter', but it still isn't the smartest.

headline: Manchester United's Old Trafford potential rebuild cost and timeframe detailed
body: Sir Jim Ratcliffe is thought to be looking to make drastic changes to Old Trafford, albeit does not wish to move the home ground from its current site.
A specialist architect has estimated how much it would cost Manchester United to rebuild Old Trafford on its current site and how long such a project would feasibly take to complete.

Sir Jim Ratcliffe is said to be considering a revamp, which may include a demolition of the current stadium with a state-of-the-art arena erected in its place. Supporters have long complained about the poor upkeep of Old Trafford with leaking roofs and run-down concourses frequently highlighted.

Previous expansion plans have been sketched, although proposals are hampered by the nearby railway line and Bridgewater Canal. Should Ratcliffe indeed wish to construct a 90,000-seater ‘Wembley of the North’ as reported, then the stadium would need to be moved inward and away from both public assets to open up enough room.

A whole-scale rebuild is set to be costly, but many feel as though the club would get more value out of the pound from that rather than an expansion, which would likely cause logistical nightmares and leave the club with a lower enhanced capacity.

Jon Leach, the sports sector lead for infrastructure consultation company Aecom, believes a rebuild on the same site would cost at least £500m, which is considered to be less than what a total relocation would require.

Any type of move would be time-consuming and Leach - who worked on schemes for the 2016 Rio Olympics - says the most realistic completion time period would be up to three years. Speaking to Building.co.uk in 2022, he explained how a top-of-the-range stadium would cost around half-a-billion pounds.
“I’d say 30 months would be better [than a two-year timeframe]. Three years, you should be able to do it [a new-build] in that,” he added.

Leach suggested that a stadium rebuild would likely impact on-field elements such as transfers and player wages. He questioned: “If you need to invest in new players, can you afford to invest in a new stadium?”

United may wish to look at the projects that saw Arsenal and Tottenham construct new home grounds, as well as Wembley Stadium, which was opened in 2007. Clare Gallagher was a senior engineer on the building of The Emirates Stadium, which was completed in 2006.
“Getting the brief right in the first place is absolutely key,” she said. “If you change it during construction, it presents more challenges. It puts pressure on the budgets and times.

“To get the budget right, you have to get the brief right. FM [facility management] is absolutely key as well. Stadium security and safety have to be built in, so you have to get the end user involved in the process from the start.”

Speaking on what made Arsenal’s move so successful, Gallagher added: “The client knew what it wanted and communicated that. The brief was very clear from very early doors. We were all very much one team. All decisions were made in the interest of the project.”
For example: “[Arsene Wenger] asked for a column in the changing room to be moved. He wanted to be able to walk in and have eye-to-eye contact with everyone. So, the column got removed.”

Another unnamed contractor said United ought to take time to get the blueprint correct but to not be alarmed if plans have to be altered: “Stadiums go wrong because they are unique designs and, typically, the design isn’t completed at the start. My advice to Manchester United would be this: design it right at the start, don’t rush it and take your time.”

headline: Manchester United have simple target to meet with Old Trafford stadium plans
body: Ineos are considering the plans laid out for the redevelopment of Old Trafford but the next decision made has to last the test of time.

When Manchester United visited Goodison Park in November it wasn't hard to pick up the whiff of a club in crisis. Railing against the corrupt Premier League, dreading what their 10-point deduction for breaching financial rules might do to their season and fearing another charge coming further down the line.

Everton are treading a delicately fine line at the moment. Financially they remain in a tight spot and after Luton's resurgence, they are in the relegation zone and facing another possible points deduction for breaching the Premier League's Profit and Sustainability rules.

But travel a couple of miles south-west of Goodison and the future of Everton is reaching up into the skyline next to the Mersey. A club constrained by a stadium full of romance but short on modernity is looking to Bramley Moor dock and their new £550million home to transform them into a top-half club once again.

To achieve that, Everton need to ride out the storm and that means Premier League survival, but when this stadium opens - probably sometime in 2025 - it will be one of their best in England. It will certainly be one of the best in the north west.

At that point, United should have decided on how to proceed with their own home. Old Trafford might not be comparable to Goodison Park in terms of a lack of space and a lack of facilities, but a ground that set the standard in this country 20 years ago has been overtaken. It isn't the best stadium in England any more, it isn't the best stadium in the north west, in fact it isn't even the best stadium in Manchester.

That honour goes to the Etihad, soon to be increased in capacity with a new hotel built on-site and improvements made to the City Square fan zone. It will put the ground in contention to host a Champions League final in the future.

City benefitted from inheriting the City of Manchester Stadium after Manchester hosted the Commonwealth Games in 2002, but they have remained on top of stadium development and it is a spectacular home for a stunning football team. At Everton, redeveloping Goodison has never been possible due to its location and they have had some torturous and controversial projects come and go before settling on a city centre location that will make it a must-visit venue.

They will no longer be split by Stanley Park from Liverpool's Anfield home. That is an example of a club that has found a way to redevelop its existing stadium. Under the ownership of Fenway Sports Group, they have rebuilt the Main Stand and increased the size of the second tier on the Anfield Road End. It has increased capacity by around 15,000 and, perhaps as importantly, significantly improved the corporate offering.

There is an argument to make that, once Bramley Moor opens, United will have the third or fourth-best stadium in the north west. Old Trafford is rich in history and vast in size, but the roof leaks, the facilities aren't up to standard and the offering around the stadium is poor. United still make more than their Premier League rivals on matchday, but the potential isn't being maximised.

With regulatory approval for Ineos' 25% stake in the club nearing approval, movement on plans for Old Trafford is expected. The options on the table are relatively simple. It would take around £800m to redevelop the current ground, which primarily involves work on the Sir Bobby Charlton Stand, which is the only single-tier stand at the stadium and has seen better days.

The issue with that is building over the railway line and it presents complex challenges. The more expensive option, which may push costs towards the £2bn mark, is to build a new ground on the vast footprint of the Old Trafford site. United could continue to play in their own ground while work on the new stadium takes place, which is likely to be behind the current Stretford End.

Sir Jim Ratcliffe put £245m into the club for infrastructure improvements when his minority ownership was confirmed on Christmas Eve, but with work also on the agenda at Carrington, that figure is a drop in the ocean compared to what is actually required. Funding work on a new stadium would be difficult, especially given the unusual ownership structure at United, which now sees Ratcliffe calling the shots but the Glazers still owning most of the club.

But United must find a way to make it work and building a new stadium must surely be the preferred option. While this is a club that once set the standards, that is no longer the case. Old Trafford might remain the biggest stadium in the Premier League, but it isn't the best.

Arsenal's 2006 move to the Emirates Stadium began the charge of clubs moving into glorious new homes. Tottenham's new ground - built adjacent to White Hart Lane - is now the gold standard in the Premier League.

That is the standard United must aspire to. Improving the existing Old Trafford might be the choice of romantics, but the long-term question should be whether that work will stand the test of time. If the answer is no, then a new stadium is the obvious choice.
It could take years to come to fruition, but then this is a long-term project. Whatever United do should be aimed at once again giving the biggest and the best stadium in the Premier League.

headline: The writing is on the wall for former Manchester United 'undroppable' in summer transfer window
body: Christian Eriksen is out of contract in the summer of 2025 but a departure at the end of the season looks likely.
Manchester United midfielder Christian Eriksen was considered undroppable for the first half of last season, which meant his signing on a free transfer represented excellent value.

There was a relationship developed between Casemiro, Eriksen and Bruno Fernandes and that settled trio became key after a worrying start to the campaign for Erik ten Hag. Casemiro made his first start for United against Everton in October 2022, playing alongside Eriksen and Fernandes, and those three were used in 10 of the next 12 league games.

It was only disrupted by Eriksen being absent for a game due to illness and Fernandes picking up a suspension. United drew against Newcastle and lost against Aston Villa in those two matches and many felt the enforced midfield changes were to blame for the performances.

Eriksen helped control the centre of the pitch when he started and his absence was obvious when he didn't feature, making him one of the first names on the team sheet. However, he sustained an ankle injury against Reading in the FA Cup last January after a tackle from Andy Carroll.

“I'm disappointed about that," Ten Hag said about the challenge. "I think football has to set limits, restrictions, that protect the players. What football wants is the best players to be available on the pitch.
“This is a tackle - and the two tackles after it – that don’t belong on a pitch, because there is a high risk of injuring your colleague. So it's worse and I'm left wondering about that.

“I'm also wondering more, when we were at Crystal Palace, when there was an elbow on Lisandro Martinez. I don't believe there was even a whistle for a free-kick and I'm wondering about such things, because it's a risk of injury for the player."

Eriksen returned from the sidelines in April but the 31-year-old looked weary and short of legs. He started 13 league games from January until the end of the campaign and played a full game just once. It was obvious his involvement had been carefully managed.

The player's physical limitations were exposed in a handful of matches and Mason Mount was signed from Chelsea to become his successor. The 25-year-old promised to lead the midfield press while providing verge and energy, but his time at the club so far hasn't worked out.

Mount has encountered different injury problems since signing for United and he did not look suited to a deeper midfield role at the beginning of the season. Many have wondered why Mount was signed when Kobbie Mainoo was expected to break into the first-team.

Before pre-season, Mainoo was informed he would be kept around the senior squad and his outstanding performances in recent weeks have been no surprise. Casemiro, Mainoo and Fernandes already looks like the strongest midfield-three available and Eriksen has consequently not been involved in the last three matches.

Mount is closing in on a return to injury and could push Eriksen further down the midfield pecking order, which suggests it's likely he will leave at the end of the season. The Denmark international will celebrate his 32nd birthday next week and there are reports of interest from Galatasaray, who are said to be preparing to sign him from United.

Eriksen is out of contract in 2025 and United have an opportunity this summer to bank a fee for a player they signed on a free transfer. He has been important for United but his importance has clearly waned.

headline: Manchester United might need a favour from Man City and Liverpool FC
body: Man Utd are on their best run of form all season and head to Villa Park this weekend with the chance to reignite their Champions League hopes.

It was a run of fixtures that could have finally ended Manchester United's slim hopes of qualifying for next season's Champions League. But instead a run of games arguably as gruelling as they have faced this season has instead given Erik ten Hag's side a pulse when it comes to salvaging their Premier League campaign.

Four of their last five league games have been against top-half sides, with three of them against teams ahead of them at the time, but United lost just one - and that was against the only side they faced in the bottom half of the table. The wins against Aston Villa, Wolves and West Ham and the draw against Tottenham have made for a positive few weeks.

The defeat at the City Ground is the only loss in the last seven games and although there are still flaws to iron out, Ten Hag can suddenly look ahead with some positivity. His side are into the FA Cup fifth round and back up to sixth in the Premier League.

For most of this season returning to the Champions League has looked almost impossible, but after that string of encouraging league results it no longer feels quite as unlikely. United are eight points behind Aston Villa in fourth and six behind Tottenham in fifth and that could yet be enough this season if English clubs achieve enough success in Europe to end the year in the top two in the UEFA coefficients table.

How United could desperately do with that bonus, even if it means hoping Manchester City and Liverpool progress in the Champions League and the Europa League once European action resumes this month. The early exit from continental competition of both Manchester United and Newcastle United has damaged the chances of securing enough points to guarantee that bonus spot, but there are enough teams left in Europe to make an impact and Arsenal, West Ham, Brighton and Aston Villa can all play their part.

It's a convoluted system that United will now be paying closer attention to. If the Champions League looked a long way away at the end of 2023, it is suddenly back on the agenda. At a time when the Premier League's financial rules are causing ongoing headaches at Old Trafford, securing the revenues that Champions League football brings is absolutely vital, not to mention the prestige and the glamourous ties.

But before United look too closely to Anfield and the Etihad for favours, they can get their own season firmly back on track this weekend. A second Premier League win against Aston Villa in the space of seven weeks will propel them back into the discussion for a top-four finish.

That Boxing Day success over Villa saw Rasmus Hojlund get his first Premier League goal and he has scored in his three subsequent starts in the competition. United are suddenly firing in front of goal and that is making a big difference.

Conversely, Villa have won just two of their last six Premier League games, against Burnley and Sheffield United. With their own European commitments set to resume next month they might find it gets harder to last the pace. If United can maintain their form and put Unai Emery's side under pressure then they might yet be able to reel them in.

They will certainly find that easier if they can win at Villa Park on Sunday. Sheffield United's draw there before Christmas and Newcastle's win last week has made it less of a fortress than it appeared to be and Ten Hag's side have already had great joy exploiting their high-line recently. Hojlund, Alejandro Garnacho and Marcus Rashford will fancy their chances of doing so again.

If they can close that gap to five points then it will throw the race for Champions League qualification wide open and United will be in the mix. That isn't a scenario that looked likely a couple of months ago.
They might still need a favour from some of their rivals in Europe, but that might be worth it if it gets United back into the Champions League and the financial advantages that come with it.

headline: Roy Keane says former Manchester United teammate 'could have done more' in career
body: Former Man United captain Roy Keane has suggested that Lee Sharpe could have achieved more during his career but admitted that the winger was a 'good guy'
Roy Keane believes former Manchester United teammate Lee Sharpe could have achieved more with his career.

Keane and Sharpe played together at Manchester United from 1993 until 1996. One of their most memorable moments came when Sharpe scored a fantastic goal against Barcelona in the 1994/95 Champions League, backheeling a cross from Keane into the net.

By age 19, Sharpe had already received his first England call-up and established himself as United's first-choice winger. However, his position on the left side was contested by Ryan Giggs following injury and illness. Sharpe also found his opportunities limited due to Dennis Irwin and David Beckham's performances, while manager Sir Alex Ferguson regularly scrutinised the midfielder's play.

After leaving United for Leeds in a £4.5million transfer, Sharpe's career continued to be disrupted by injury. Loan spells at Sampdoria and Bradford followed before Sharpe made a permanent move to the Bantams. He then saw out his career with stints at Everton, Grindavik and Garforth Town.

Despite his successful career, Keane insinuated that Sharpe could have accomplished even more if he'd shown more motivation. Speaking on the Stick to Football podcast, brought to you by Sky Bet, the former Sunderland and Ipswich boss said: "Lee Sharpe was quite laid back, but he was a good guy.

"Maybe he would be the first to admit that he had little success in his career but could have done more if he tried harder. I think he would be honest enough to say that because he was so laid back and had the manager on his case all the time.

"But then he went up to Leeds and got a bad injury, but I think overall, I think Sharpie would admit that he could have done more in his career, but he didn't have that real hunger and desire to maintain a high standard over a long period of time."
Keane suggested that Sharpe did not respond well to Ferguson's 'tough love' towards the end of his time in Manchester. He suggested that his former teammate noted he had stopped listening.

The 52-year-old pundit explained: "With managers giving players tough love, I remember seeing an interview recently with Lee Sharpe, and he really loved his football and off the field he had fun as well, especially with his dancing, but he said towards the end of his time at Manchester United, when Sir Alex Ferguson was having a go at him, he said that he just stopped listening."

headline: Lisandro Martinez has told Erik ten Hag what he wanted to hear amid Man United injury blow
body: Manchester United defender Lisandro Martinez sustained a knee injury against West Ham and will be out for around two months
Lisandro Martinez will hope it's third time lucky when he returns for Manchester United's run-in.

The defender is set to be out for eight weeks after sustaining a knee injury against West Ham on Sunday. It's his third prolonged injury absence in under a year and is a huge blow to Erik ten Hag as he tries to steer United into the Champions League places.

Martinez is a key lieutenant for Ten Hag, having followed the manager from Ajax. His position in the defence is pivotal to United's style of play and the centre-back could now be absent for nine first-team fixtures across the Premier League and FA Cup.

He's already missed 34 matches since signing for United through two separate injuries but the combative 26-year-old has twice returned to the coalface in fine fettle. He will hope his next comeback is more permanent.

Either way, Martinez won't be a despondent figure on the sidelines. He'll knuckle down with his trademark tenacity to get back to full fitness at the first available opportunity while he's already outlined how he can use an enforced absence to build his knowledge in other areas.

“It is part of football also and we need to accept it, be humble," he said, speaking in a club interview in December while sidelined. "It is a time to work even harder, in the gym, improving, doing analysis, doing tactics, in the things that we can improve on the pitch.
“As a person as well, I love to improve that part because, for everybody, if you improve then automatically you will see it on the pitch."

Martinez will be supported by the medical staff at United and his teammates, as well as friends and family. And the World Cup winner is well-versed in overcoming quickfire injuries having only been fully fit for a number of weeks at the start of the campaign between his two absences.

“It is tough, so tough," he added of that time. "Especially when you had two injuries, almost six or seven months, it is really, really tough. But I feel strong from my mind. I get really good values from my family, to never give up, so this has only made me even stronger. It is tough, so tough, but there are no excuses."

headline: Premier League chief makes damning new VAR admission as Manchester United and Man City wait
body: Changes in VAR are imminent after the Premier League accepted that the video assistant referee was taking too long in news which will delight Manchester City and Man United fans

Premier League chief football officer, Tony Scholes, has accepted that improvements must be made to VAR in the future while also making comments on possible changes likely to affect Manchester United and Manchester City.

Scholes has admitted that VAR decisions take too long and provide a poor in-stadium experience for supporters, whilst going on to acknowledge there are too many checks. The Premier League chief's comments come after the league admitted it was not in a position to confirm whether semi-automatic offside technology would be introduced for next season.

Despite declaring he feels VAR has been a largely successful addition to the Premier League, with the number of correct decisions increasing from 82 per cent to 96 per cent, Scholes admitted that changes would be made.

"VAR is and remains a very effective tool in supporting the match officials on the pitch... but clearly everything in the world of VAR is not perfect," Scholes said. "We're aware of that and we know that we have work to do.

"There are two elements that I believe affect the whole reputation of VAR. [First] is the time that it takes to do the reviews, or to do the checks. We're doing too many checks, we're taking too long doing them as well.
"It's to a degree understandable given the level of scrutiny these guys are under, but the reviews are taking too long and it's affecting the flow of the game.

"The second area where the VAR experience is poor is the in-stadium experience for the supporter. It's nowhere near good enough. We know it's not. It affects supporters' enjoyment of the game, and we know it needs to change."

Scholes also discussed the topic of playing audio footage between VAR and on-field referees, though did admit that it isn't close to becoming official. "We are constrained in what we can by IFAB and IFAB is very clear at the moment we cannot use the audio," he added.
"My personal view is that we'll get to the point where both the video and the audio is played live and then played afterwards to explain the decision. How far away from that we are, I don't know."

headline: Manchester United 'open door' for Jadon Sancho return and other transfer rumours
body: Manchester United winger Jadon Sancho is currently on loan at Borussia Dortmund after a public disagreement with Erik ten Hag in September
Manchester United are reportedly willing to allow Jadon Sancho to return to the first-team fold should Erik ten Hag leave the club in the summer.

Sancho has not featured for United since August after a public fallout with Ten Hag in September. During his post-match press conference following the defeat to Arsenal, the Dutchman was asked why the English forward had not made the squad.

Ten Hag replied that he was not impressed with his efforts in training, a comment which caused Sancho to declare was 'untrue' before naming himself a 'scapegoat'. His social media outburst was deleted but the damage was already done and the winger was shunned into exile by the United manager.

In January, Sancho rejoined Borussia Dortmund on loan but an agreement to make the deal permanent in the summer was not reached. According to Football Insider, a decision on the winger's future is being postponed until the end of the season with one of their sources claiming the 23-year-old could have a part to play at Old Trafford if Ten Hag is sacked.
MEN Sport understands INEOS have no immediate plans to replace Ten Hag as manager. Elsewhere, Bayern Munich are reportedly ready to usurp United in the race to sign Barcelona defender Ronald Araujo.

The 24-year-old has been linked with a move to the Reds this season as Ten Hag aims to bolster his centre-back options. However, Sport understands Bayern are starting to take the initiative and are willing to double Araujo's current salary.
Barcelona have previously declared they are unwilling to sell the Uruguayan and see him as a crucial member of their future plans.

headline: Manchester United heading towards a civil war as Old Trafford plans debated
body: Manchester United's incoming co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe is beginning to turn attention towards improving the Reds' stadium but fans are split on how to do it
Manchester United are expecting to gain ratification from the Premier League for Sir Jim Ratcliffe's 25 per cent acquisition of the club in the coming days.

Ratcliffe has been in Manchester this week paying his respects to the Busby Babes but has taken the opportunity to crack on with other matters surrounding the club. MEN Sport understands he has undergone meetings at both Old Trafford and Carrington as he prepares to take the reins.

INEOS are 'getting down to business' at United as they begin the task of bringing the club back to elite status in both England and Europe. With plenty needing to be prioritised, the future of Old Trafford is currently at the forefront of the discussion.
MEN Sport has taken a look at the latest stories surrounding United and given our take.

The Theatre of Dreams requires a makeover after being neglected for too long. Earlier this week, reports surfaced suggesting Ratcliffe was in favour of building a new stadium in the vicinity of Old Trafford rather than developing the existing ground.

INEOS' founder believes fans will be receptive to the idea of a new stadium which does not depart from its current location dramatically. However, the Glazers believe that Old Trafford should simply be renovated rather than being demolished and replaced.
Ironically after years of opposition, the majority of supporters are likely to agree with the American family on this one point.

MEN Sport says: Ratcliffe finds himself in a catch-22 scenario here as he looks to bring United into the 21st century. On the one hand, his intentions are admirable and the construction of a brand new stadium would perhaps make more financial sense.
However, Old Trafford remains one of the most iconic venues in sport even in its current unloved state. Demolishing it would see a part of United die.

At a time when some of the world's best stadiums are closing their doors for good, it would be nice if the Reds could buck the trend. If he is not careful, Ratcliffe could have a civil war on his hands over how to get this job done.

Reports on Wednesday suggested United captain Bruno Fernandes could be denied a stacked new contract by INEOS when they arrive. The 29-year-old will have another two years remaining on his current deal in the summer but it is believed he wants to extend his stay.
However, Ratcliffe and co are thought to be unwilling to offer an ageing player a lucrative contract which could open the door for Fernandes' exit in the next year or so.
MEN Sport says: On his day, Fernandes has proven his worth to the club. His actions on the pitch may split opinion but his creativity is something which United lack.

As captain, he is showing signs of maturity too and has become undroppable under Ten Hag. However, signing players onto long-term lucrative deals when they are past 30 has been the Reds' undoing for the past decade.

INEOS are right to be wary of agreeing to huge proposals when he will be 31 come the end of his current contract. United need to learn to budget wiser and Ratcliffe's hand on the pursestrings could bring that about.
Hopefully, an agreement can be reached as it would be a shame to lose Fernandes from this squad in 2026.

headline: When is UEFA Nations League draw - Stream details, time, pots and what it means for World Cup
body: The draw for the 2024-25 UEFA Nations League takes place on February 8, with England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland all hoping for a favourable outcome
England's football team, led by Gareth Southgate, is gearing up to find out who they'll be playing against in the next UEFA Nations League tournament.
The last time around, England didn't win a single match in their group, which included Italy, Hungary and Germany. In fact, the 2022-23 tournament was a mixed bag for all of the home nations.
Both England and Wales failed to secure a victory, while Scotland topped their group and Northern Ireland stayed in League C. Spain took home the trophy after beating Croatia in the final.
Some teams managed to secure spots in the Euro 2024 play-offs thanks to their performance in the Nations League.
The tournament could even have huge implications for England heading into the next World Cup. Here are all the details you need to know ahead of the draw:

The next Nations League campaign will kick off in September, just two months after the Euros final. The draw for the 2024-25 UEFA Nations League will take place in Paris on February 8, 2024, at 5pm UK time.
Teams are divided into four leagues, from A (the best) to D (the least good). The top four teams in League A will compete for the title in 2025.
You can watch the draw live on UEFA's official website. They'll start with League D and finish with League A.

All 54 European teams are in the draw. Germany didn't take part in the Euro 2024 qualifying draw because they're hosting it, but they're in the Nations League. Here are the groups:

The 2024-25 edition also brings in play-offs for promotion and relegation. So, if Scotland finishes third in their group and either England or Wales comes second in theirs, they could face each other in a play-off.
The expanded 48-team World Cup in 2026 will have 16 teams from Europe. Twelve spots will go to the winners of 12 qualifying groups, while the runners-up will get another chance in a play-off round.

The 12 runners-up will be joined by four more teams in the play-off round. These teams might not have finished in the top two of their group, but they've earned a spot through their Nations League performances. This means that doing well in the Nations League could lead to a place in the tournament in the United States, Mexico and Canada.

headline: Nottingham Forest vs Man United FA Cup fifth-round tie confirmed date, TV channel and stream

Manchester United's FA Cup fifth-round opponents have been confirmed after Nottingham Forest beat Bristol City in a fourth-round replay on Wednesday evening.

It means that Erik ten Hag's team will now travel to the City Ground for a mid-week cup encounter under the lights in two weeks. The Red Devils reached the final last season but were beaten 2-1 by neighbours Manchester City at Wembley.

United have won the historic trophy 12 times in their history with only Arsenal ahead of their all-time record with 14. Ten Hag will be hoping to go one better this season with the FA Cup now United's only realistic hope of finishing the current campaign with any silverware.

headline: Manchester United defender Harry Amass takes part in first-team training aged 16
body: Man United youngster Harry Amass is highly regarded and he took part in first-team training at Carrington this week.
Harry Amass trained with Manchester United's first-team at Carrington on Wednesday, despite being aged just 16 years old.

Amass signed for United from Watford last summer and he's considered one of the most exciting talents in English football. The left-back has made 14 appearances in academy matches this season and he's become a key player in an U18 United side that has won every game in the league.

The youngster trained with the first team on Wednesday afternoon in preparation for Aston Villa and he was joined by Sam Mather (19) and Toby Collyer (20). It's unusual for a 16-year-old to train with the senior group but Amass was selected to make up the numbers.
It's understood Under-21 manager Travis Binnion advises the first-team coaching staff on which youngsters should make the step up when extra numbers are required in training.
Erik ten Hag's assistant coach Mitchell van der Gaag has developed a healthy relationship with Binnion over the last 18 months and he is often the link between the first team and academy.
Amass' performances for the U18s this season have not gone unnoticed and the opportunity to gain senior training experience is the reward for those displays.
Watford were desperate to keep hold of Amass beyond his scholarship deal but United won the race for his signature. The defender will celebrate his 17th birthday next month.
Omari Forson and Willy Kambwala, who were both recently given their debuts, were involved in training again following their promotion to the first-team squad this term.

headline: Why Manchester United youngster Alvaro Fernandez isn't starting for Benfica on loan
body: Man Utd's Alvaro Fernandez was recalled from his loan with Granada to sign for Benfica in the January transfer window.
Although Manchester United loanee Alvaro Fernandez has yet to start for Benfica since joining the club on loan, their manager has insisted he is happy with the youngster.
Fernandez was recalled from his Granada loan so he could sign for Benfica for the remainder of the season and the deal includes an obligation to buy if he starts 50 per cent of games.

Benfica will pay €6million plus €3m in potential add-ons and they will still have the option to buy Fernandez if that obligation isn't triggered, while United have also inserted a buy-back clause and a sell-on fee if he is sold to another club after spending time in Portugal.
United believe they negotiated a good deal for Fernandez and the details in his Benfica contract mean it's likely he will not represent his parent club in Manchester again.
The expectation is Benfica will sign Fernandez on a permanent deal, but the left-back has got off to a slow start in Lisbon and he's yet to be given a start for his new club.
Fernandez has played just 30 minutes since signing for Benfica and their manager, Roger Schmidt, was asked about him this week, telling A Bola: “Alvaro is doing well in training.

"He has already played a few minutes, but in the future he could also play as a starter. He is working well, he is a player capable of quickly understanding tactical behaviours, he adapts quickly and I am looking forward to seeing him on the field.”
Morato, 22, is the first-choice left-back at Benfica after converting from central defence and Fernandez has the challenge of breaking into the team ahead of the Brazilian.

Fernandez failed to make his debut for United and felt he was forced to leave on loan. “What message did United give me? That I should go out on loan, that Ten Hag didn’t count on me, that I should continue to gain experience, rhythm, and we’ll see what happens in the future," he told The Athletic in December.
"But it’s clear that football doesn’t end at any club and that you have to keep working. My main objective is to return to United and make a place for myself there.”
Luke Shaw and Tyrell Malacia are the senior players in Fernandez's position and the player believed his pathway to the first-team was blocked.

headline: Jesse Lingard explains FC Seoul transfer
body: Man United academy graduate Jesse Lingard has joined South Korean club FC Seoul on a permanent deal.
Former Manchester United midfielder Jesse Lingard believes a shock move to South Korea is the 'perfect place' for him to reignite his career.
The United academy graduate sealed a move to FC Seoul earlier this week, with the club confirming his arrival on Thursday. He has joined the South Korean outfit on a two-year deal.

The 31-year-old, who left Old Trafford in June 2022, had been without a club since leaving Nottingham Forest at the end of last season. He signed a one-year deal at the City Ground in July 2022 and made just 20 appearances for the club.

Following his departure from the Midlands, Lingard spent time in Saudi Arabia, training with Al Ettifaq, who are managed by former Liverpool captain Steven Gerrard. A deal, however, failed to come to fruition.

Lingard received a collection of offers in pursuit of a new club, but he has settled on a move to Seoul, who play in K League 1. He was impressed by the level of interest they expressed in him and was keen to repay them by joining them.
Lingard, speaking at his official unveiling, said: "I'm very excited. It is a new challenge, but I have accepted it.

"I'm here, I'm ready to embrace the culture, it is a new beginning for me, a new chapter in my career and I just want to enjoy playing football again. I want to put a smile on people's faces and show the Korean fans what I can do.

"When FC Seoul came into the equation, the commitment that they showed... they flew to Manchester to watch me train. I got put through some tests by the physios in Manchester and they came through with a contract on paper.
"The commitment shown by the club made up my mind about where I wanted to go. There was multiple offers but they were all verbal offers.
"The commitment shown by FC Seoul showed how much interest [they had] and how much they wanted me at the club, so it was only right to repay that and come to the club."
"I've always wanted a different challenge and to create new memories in my career," Lingard added, speaking in a separate interview. "I believe South Korea is the perfect place for that."

headline: Andre Onana could cause controversy by doing what David de Gea did at Manchester United
body: Andre Onana has struggled during his first season at Man Utd yet he has the second-highest number of clean sheets in the Premier League.
It's hard to argue Manchester United have been the best in class for anything this season. Yet, for the second year in a row, they could have a trophy to show for it.
Even after a fantastic 3-0 win against West Ham United last weekend, they sit sixth in the Premier League, with as many points separating them from the top-four as the bottom half of the table.
Whichever way you look at it, the narrative can be twisted into a pessimistic pile-on, or optimism that things might finally be changing now that they have so many key players back available.
STADIUM NEWS: What 'new' Old Trafford will look like according to AI

There is no disputing one fact, though. United have conceded more goals than they have scored so far this season. Yet, they still boast the sixth-best defensive record in the Premier League and have conceded three fewer goals than Tottenham.
It is an odd quirk that has seen Erik ten Hag's side suffer some humiliating defeats, but there have also been a flurry of narrow wins for their goal difference to currently be standing at -1.

This is perhaps no better summed up when you look at the race for the Golden Glove award. The only thing more alarming than Andre Onana sitting in second on the list is that he is behind Everton shot-stopper Jordan Pickford in the podium places.

Everton might be 18th in the table thanks to their 10-point deduction, but they have the fourth-best defensive record this season, with only the top three teams in the Premier League conceding fewer goals than them.
See, the quirk of the award is that the 'keeper with the most clean sheets is given an accolade in recognition of their achievements, but that doesn't necessarily mean they are the best goalkeeper.
Onana has kept as many clean sheets as Alisson Becker, yet the United 'keeper has conceded 32 goals and the Liverpool shot-stopper just 19 in two fewer appearances as well.

The Golden Glove Award also doesn't represent the different challenges a goalkeeper faces. It is far harder to keep clean sheets when your team is at the bottom of the table and spends the majority of matches on the back foot than it is to keep them when you are winning every week and have far less to do.
Of course, that is not a luxury afforded to Onana this season, but anyone who has watched United this season will admit he is not the best in the Premier League at this moment in time.

You only have to look at the fact that David de Gea won the award last season despite a catalogue of high-profile mistakes to question the validity of the award, especially because clean sheets are a team effort rather than down to just the person in goal.

But regardless of what happens, there is still reason to be cheerful. Onana's worst performances were in the Champions League, and on the whole, he has been pretty decent in the Premier League, despite the odd blips.

Take that recent win against West Ham, for example. It would look like a convincing home win in the end, but it could have been a very different story if not for a sharp reaction stop to keep out Tomáš Souček's deflected header in the first half.
“He has been criticised at times, but you expect your goalkeeper to make important saves in the crucial time of the game as well," Dwight Yorke said afterwards.

“I think this is a great reflex save. He is showing a good and strong left hand. He will be really pleased with that because Man United tend to concede quite a lot of goals from set-pieces and this was a possible one, but the goalkeeper did fantastically well.”
It is easy to join the Onana pile-on given his calamitous Champions League campaign, but overall, Ten Hag is happy with his choice in goal and still feels there is more to come from him.

It would actually be quite funny if a United player won the Golden Glove Award for the second season in a row, yet the very fact that De Gea is no longer at the club is enough to tell you that it doesn't tell the full story.
Onana does deserve some credit for his gradual improvement since he arrived at the club, but he will be defined by the team accolades rather than the individual ones.

headline: Manchester United could rebuild Old Trafford without moving stadium
body: Man Utd hired masterplanners Populous to look into improving Old Trafford in early 2022 and plans to enhance it could accelerate under Sir Jim Ratcliffe.
Manchester United have been advised a new build is the best option as they consider an upgrade of Old Trafford.

The Manchester Evening News understands renovation of the 114-year-old stadium would be complicated due to the railway lines and the existing structures. Although sources have suggested enhancing the stadium would be more cost-efficient than rebuilding it, the expense would still be considerable and more time-consuming.
United would also be hit by reduced capacity crowds, as they were when the north stand, now the Sir Alex Ferguson Stand, was rebuilt in 1995.

A new Old Trafford would be a higher capital cost but provide a better return on the investment and could be constructed while Old Trafford is still in use, as Tottenham did with White Hart Lane while their new stadium was under construction next door. That would prevent United from playing in front of reduced-capacity crowds.
Spurs moved out of White Hart Lane in 2017 and resided at Wembley until their new stadium opened in March 2019 due to a string of delays.

United hired stadium masterplanners Populous to present proposals for an expanded Old Trafford in April 2022. As revealed by the Manchester Evening News last year, rebuilding the stadium would enable United to rotate Old Trafford and maximise the site's footprint.
Bypassing the issue of the railway line behind the Sir Bobby Charlton Stand has prevented United from expanding the only single-tiered stand.

The prospect of United rebuilding their stadium has raised the prospect of where they would play in the interim. A senior staff member said before the strategic review commenced that there was "no chance" they would consider playing home matches at the Etihad Stadium, Manchester City's home.

Plans were presented to United before the Glazer family announced a strategic review of the club in November 2022. It was announced the Ineos Group agreed a 25% stakeholding in United on Christmas Eve.

With structural and personnel changes expected once the Ineos Group receive regulatory approval from the Premier League, it is unclear if Populous's proposals will be sanctioned by Ineos chairman Sir Jim Ratcliffe.

headline: Unai Emery demands Manchester United reaction as Aston Villa slump continues
body: Man Utd are in the inform side as they travel to face Aston Villa in the Premier League this weekend.
Unai Emery admits Aston Villa still have a lot of work to do as they prepare for a 'very important' match against Manchester United this weekend.

Villa will be trying to recover from their loss after Chelsea eliminated them from the FA Cup on Wednesday. The 3-1 defeat at Villa Park means they have now won just one of their last four home matches in all competitions.

Emery's side have won just three of their last seven matches since their Boxing Day defeat at Old Trafford, and they know three points are vital this weekend if they are to keep their Champions League dreams alive.
STADIUM NEWS: What 'new' Old Trafford will look like according to AI
By Sunday evening, the gap between the two sides could stand at 11 points or be as close as just 5 points, and Emery is eager for his side to get back on track immediately.

“We lost more balls than normal," he told reporters after the FA Cup exit. "Sometimes the performance of the players can be better or worse, but I have to try to keep balance as well, giving them chances to recover even when they have not been performing good in the match. We are facing Chelsea and they are very good players. We have to assess, I know when we are facing Chelsea in the FA Cup we are playing a contender in the competition and one to be in the top five position in the league.

“We are being consistent in our way and have to continue and build the team. There is still a lot of work to do. Against Chelsea we have to accept the defeat. We have to move on and on Sunday we have a very important game.”

headline: ‘Something isn’t right there’ - Jose Mourinho Man United verdict as manager linked with return
body: Jose Mourinho is reportedly plotting a return to Manchester United with the Portuguese manager said to have unfinished business at Manchester United.
Jose Mourinho has 'unfinished business' at Manchester United but would encounter the same old problem if he were to make a sensational return to Old Trafford.

That's according to former England defender Glen Johnson, who played under the Portuguese boss at Chelsea from 2004-2007. A report in the Daily Mail suggested that Mourinho, who was recently sacked by Serie A club AS Roma after three years in Italy, wants a second spell as Red Devils boss as he feels that his work at Old Trafford was not completed. The report claims that the 61-year-old is keen to work under the new administration brought in by INEOS and Sir Jim Ratcliffe following the billionaire's recent investment.

Mourinho took charge of the United hot seat in 2016, guiding the club to EFL Cup success at Wembley before winning the Europa League with a 2-0 win against Ajax to secure a cup double in his first season. A year later he secured a second-place finish in the Premier League before losing the FA Cup final to his former club Chelsea.

But after a poor start to his third season, Mourinho was relieved of his duties by United shortly before Christmas, bringing his project to a premature end. With current boss Erik ten Hag currently under pressure to fix the inconsistencies that have blighted United's current campaign, the club's former boss could be waiting in the wings for a second chance and retired full-back Johnson doesn't think the idea of Mourinho's return is all that far-fetched, even if he would still have to fix a familiar nagging issue.

Speaking to Betfred, Johnson said: “He’s obviously a fantastic manager and regardless of whether there’s any substance to these rumours or not, there’s definitely some unfinished business between himself and Manchester United because he doesn’t usually go to these sorts of clubs and fail.

“If he went back, it would be no different to the club that he left in the first place because the squad still isn’t good enough and they’re not performing well on a consistent basis. However, Manchester United is still a giant of a football club and on paper, their team looks pretty bloody good, but something isn’t right there.”

Mourinho has won eight league titles across Europe including three Premier League titles with Chelsea. After leaving United he had a spell with Tottenham Hotspur before joining Italian giants Roma where he helped the capital club to win the Europa Conference League in 2022, ending their 11-year trophy drought.

headline: Manchester United opponents accused of doping as Gary Neville and Roy Keane make huge claim
body: Former Manchester United captains Gary Neville and Roy Keane made the allegations as they reflected on their experiences in Europe during the mid-2000s
Former Manchester United captains Gary Neville and Roy Keane have claimed players at some of the clubs they faced in the Champions League during the mid-2000s were doping.

In the '00s, United enjoyed one of their most dominant spells in history. With Sir Alex Ferguson at the helm, the Reds won the Premier League on six occasions, the League Cup three times and the FA Cup.

However, the Champions League proved elusive until 2008 when they beat Chelsea on penalties in Moscow, ending a nine-year drought since that famous comeback against Bayern Munich to lift the trophy in 1999.

United reached the last eight in seven consecutive seasons during the late 1990s and early 2000s, also making it to the semi-final in 2002 before falling to an agonising defeat to Bayer Leverkusen. Asked about the club's toughest nights in Europe, Neville recalled on the Stick to Football podcast, brought to you by Sky Bet: "There are a couple which sticks in my mind, I am going to say this for legal reasons, I think there were a few teams we played against who weren’t clean. We thought it at the time."

Agreeing, Keane added: "We played against certain teams where I would be walking off and would be absolutely shattered and I would be looking at who I have been playing against, and they looked like they hadn’t even played a match. Why can’t we talk about that?"
Neville replied: "You can’t accuse people…" To which Jamie Carragher laughed: "You just have!"
Concluding the discussion, Neville said: "My point is when you look back at what came out after in cycling and other sports with doctors, you do think. We thought it at the time.
"Physically we were fit, we weren’t drinkers [but] that’s not right, there is something not right. I came off the pitch and I thought that’s not right, that’s not right I’m sorry.
"I know that a couple of the other lads in the mid-2000s thought exactly the same thing. That is the sort of thing for me where there are no excuses."

headline: Gary Neville spots major problem Kobbie Mainoo could have at Manchester United
body: Gary Neville has given his thoughts on the current crop of Man United youngsters, including Kobbie Mainoo, and he doesn't think they have the same support system he enjoyed
Gary Neville has expressed his worries about the new generation of stars at Manchester United, saying they may struggle due to a lack of leaders in the dressing room.

The former United player, who was part of the famous Class of 92, thinks that the current crop of young players like Kobbie Mainoo don't have the same support system he had. Mainoo has been a shining star for United this season, becoming a regular in Erik ten Hag's midfield.

He's leading a group of young players, including Omari Forson, Willy Kambwala and Amad Diallo, who are all vying for starting positions despite their tender years. But Neville has raised his concerns about the players' development.

"It's a massive factor, the dressing room that you come into as a young player and the influence and standard bearers in the dressing room," Neville said on the Stick to Football podcast, brought to you by Sky Bet.

"These [Manchester] United lads who have come through in the last five to eight years, if you’re a young lad coming through at Liverpool and Manchester City you’ve got a good chance, whereas if you’re at United now, you’re thinking who's guiding that dressing room."
Former United captain Keane agrees with Neville's views on the current team under Ten Hag. He joined United from Nottingham Forest in 1993 and was instantly impressed by the dressing room atmosphere.

"I loved the dressing room," he said. "I thought all these players were brilliant professionals, and I looked around and thought what a great group of people. Players like Bryan Robson, Ryan Giggs and Lee Sharpe, all amazing professional players.

"Remember the Cliff, our old training ground in Salford, I'd come in for a big fee at the time, but I was looking around the group and even the chat and the banter was great. My first pre-season we went to South Africa, and I couldn't believe how brilliant It was and how good the players were.

"We're talking about plenty of players when we played who would happily give tough love, but clearly no one is doing that at Manchester United for Marcus Rashford and that is one of the problems that the team has, they don't have that core group of players."

headline: Manchester United's Old Trafford decision raises key questions for future of the club
body: Sir Jim Ratcliffe and INEOS face a huge decision over the future of Old Trafford, with options ranging from renovation work to a full rebuild of the Theatre of Dreams

While most of the talk surrounding Sir Jim Ratcliffe's minority takeover of Manchester United has focused on squad planning, given that the timing of the deal coincided with the January transfer window, the British billionaire and INEOS face big questions off the pitch as well - namely the future of Old Trafford.

The fate of the Theatre of Dreams may not necessarily seem an immediate issue given United have problems to solve on the pitch given their disappointing form this season, but in a new era of Premier League financial regulations, a modern stadium looks set to be a dividing line when it comes to clubs' ambitions to be among the elite. Though Old Trafford is undoubtedly one of the UK's most impressive stadiums in terms of history, romance and sheer scale, it is no secret that Ratcliffe must make big changes if he is to realise his ambitions of returning United to the top table - both domestically and in Europe.

There are multiple options in terms of what to do with the 114-year-old stadium. The Manchester Evening News understands renovations would be difficult due to the railway lines and the existing structures, and they have been advised a new build is the best option. Though enhancing the stadium would be cheaper than a full rebuild, it would take time and mean reduced capacity crowds, hitting United in the pocket during a period when the club has sailed close to the line in meeting the Premier League Profit and Sustainability Rules (PSR).

Another option would be to follow Tottenham's approach and build a new stadium in close proximity to Old Trafford, playing at the famous stadium while construction work is done. According to the Telegraph, Ratcliffe's grand plan is to create a "Wembley of the North" in a full revamp which would turn the stadium into a world-leading venue.

But each new option brings with it a tug at the heart-strings: few stadia have quite the romance of Old Trafford, with many nights of famous wins, trophies, legends and memories attached to it. It would be remiss to think of the Theatre of Dreams as mere bricks and mortar, and Ratcliffe will have to ensure that any decision made on the future of the stadium acknowledges just how special the ground is to millions of supporters.

While decisions will eventually be taken, we want to know what you, the fans, think about the future of Old Trafford.
